Description: Rim and body sherd of South Ionian pottery cup with everted rim; interior: reserved band at top, glazed black below; exterior: narrow black band over top of lip, which is reserved below; glazed black on body save for reserved handle zone.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B2
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by Royal Ontario Museum, Toronto. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Although Schlotzhauer (Schlotzhauer 2012) does not discuss this sherd, the shape and decoration find parallels with his South Ionian cups with everted rim Type 9A. The type closely follows the shape and decoration of the Attic Plain Komast cups. These cups coincide with Petrie’s class L1 (Petrie 1886, 18), Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type IX (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116), and Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type b2 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Type 9 cups have been found in large numbers in other sanctuary settings including at the Sanctuary of Aphrodite at Miletus, the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra, and at the site of Megara Hyblaea on Sicily. This type was the most common type of South Ionian cups with everted rims found at Naukratis. The Type 9 shape evolved from the earlier Type 5 cup shape. "Rhodian", early version of Tocra type IX. This particular version is common at Naukratis: see Naukratis I, pl. 10: also Fairbanks, Boston Cat. no. 332, pl. XXXVII. Same version at Tocra: Tocra I 120, no 1218. fig. 55; for the type in general see p.113 (Hayes 1984 p.7, no. 7 p. 8, fig. 7). Hayes 1984 offers a different date of production, at about 600-575 BC
Bibliographic references: Hayes 1984 / Greek and Italian Black-Gloss Wares and Related Wares in the Royal Ontario Museum (p. 7, no. 7, p. 8, fig. 7)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.271) (Phase 3)
